system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on March 1, 2024, presenting with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and shortness of breath. Upon evaluation, an Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed the presence of an ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI). A diagnosis of an acute transmural myocardial infarction of the anterior wall was established.

On the same day of admission, you underwent a Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) with stent placement, which stabilized your condition. Your vital signs remained stable post-procedure, and you reported no recurrent chest pain. Continuous monitoring was maintained throughout your stay.

On March 2, 2024, during the ward round, it was noted that you felt better, with effective pain management, and a decrease in troponin levels was observed. Medications were initiated including Aspirin (325 mg once daily), Clopidogrel (75 mg once daily), an IV Heparin infusion, Nitroglycerin for PRN chest pain, Metoprolol (50 mg twice daily), Lisinopril (10 mg once daily), and a Statin (40 mg daily).

You showed significant improvement and, by March 3, 2024, discharge preparations, including discussions on rehabilitation, were in progress. Your condition remained stable, and you expressed understanding of your medication regimen.

By March 4, 2024, pre-discharge checks confirmed your readiness for discharge, with all medications reviewed, and discharge instructions provided. You were formally discharged on March 6, 2024, having remained clinically stable without complications throughout your hospital stay.

You are scheduled to attend a follow-up appointment at the cardiology outpatient clinic on March 20, 2024, to assess your recovery and medication management. It is important that you adhere to the prescribed medication regimen and lifestyle modifications discussed with you. These include adopting a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats, cholesterol, and sodium, with increased intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Gradual reintroduction of physical activity, starting with light walking, aims to build up to at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week. Immediate smoking cessation is critical, and options for nicotine replacement therapy and counseling are available to support quitting. Managing stress through mindfulness, yoga, or meditation, with professional support if needed, is also encouraged.

Thank you for your cooperation and understanding during your hospital stay. Please contact your healthcare provider if you have any questions or concerns prior to your follow-up appointment.

Sincerely,

___
